title: Marsh - Billings - Rockefeller National Historical Park: Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller Mansion
body: Explore This Park    Learn About the Park     History & Culture     Places     Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller Mansion                Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller Mansion         Mansion Ed Sharron  The Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller Mansion was originally constructed as a brick house in the Federal-style by Charles Marsh in 1805. It was purchased by Frederick Billings in 1869 and remodeled in the fashionable French Second Empire Style. Fifteen years later, Billings enlarged and remodeled the house in the Queen Anne Style. Billings' granddaughter, Mary French Rockefeller, inherited the property in 1954. She and her husband, Laurance Rockefeller, adapted the home for modern living. Today the home remains the way the Rockefellers left it in 1997. Guided tours of the museum are offered daily from Memorial Day weekend through October. To learn more about the Mansion, https://www.nps.gov/mabi/planyourvisit/mansion-and-gardens.htm          Collections Specialist Marianne Zephir and Horticulturalist Kim Murray reconstruct a Rockefeller-era silk flower table decoration, working from a photograph. NPS Photo  The table will be set. . . in the dining room at the park's Mansion this year! Visitors on ranger-guided tours will be able to enter the dining room and walk around a table set with the family's dinnerware. Join us for programs beginning this year on Saturday May 28, 2016!        Mansion Foyer Billings Family Archives  Mansion Foyer          Mansion Parlor Billings Family Archive  Mansion Parlor        Mansion Bedroom Billings Family Archives  Mansion Bedroom        Mansion Library Billings Family Archive  Mansion Library
